div1.p: These five memorandums concern a missing letter, called the “Round Robin letter,” in which the 5th Army Corps general officers recommended that the Army be pulled from Cuba and sent north. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Memorandum, April 15, [18]99
div1.p:
The question of the where-
abouts of the original letter
(officers of 5th Army Corps.)
known as the round robin, being
brought up by Col. McCain, Actg.
Adjt. General, on July 26, 1912,
no further light was thrown upon
the question than is contained in
the papers 241037.
July 27, 1912.

The Round Robin letter was
telegraphed by Genl. Shafter from
Santiago Aug. 3, 1898 and was
signed by all of the general offi-
cers of the 5th Army Corps and Col.
Roosevelt.

For this telegram please see
A. G. O. 241037 Addl. C herewith

The original letter to Genl.
Shafter has never been found among
the records.

A press copy of General
Shafter's telegram of August 3,
communicating what has been
called the “Round Robbin Letter”,
signed by the general officers
in the 5th Army Corps, recommend-
ing that the Army be at once
taken out of Cuba and sent North,
is found in the 5th Corps book
of “Letters and Telegrams Sent”
from General Shafter's headquar-
ters; [unclear] but the original letter
itself, signed by the officers, is
not found among the records from
the 5th Corps.

General Roosevelt's letter of
July 31, to General Wheeler,
commanding the Cavalry Division,
strongly urging that the brigade
commanded by General Roosevelt be
sent North immediately, with an
indorsement of General Wheeler,
of August 1, recommending that
the Cavalry Division be sent to
Porto Rico, or, if not there, to
some other healthy locality, is
found on file. It is
impossible to ascertain, from any
record that can be found, the
conditions attached to General
Wheeler's signature to the
“Round Robbin Letter”.

See also telegram General
Shafter to Adjutant General,
Aug.3, in regard to moving 5th
Corps to end of railroad; that is
his opinion the only course to
take is to immediately transport
the entire Army with the least
delay possible to the United
States, and saying that he had
called together the general offi-
cers and the senior medical offi-
cers, who sustain his views, and
whose views are telegraphed; also
telegram General Shafter, same
date, giving text of letter from
the Chief Surgeons, 5th Corps,
urging that the command be sent
to the United States as soon as
possible.

The “Round Robbin Letter”
was telegraphed by General Shaf-
ter from Santiago August 3, and
signed by all or nearly all of
the general officers then on
duty in the corps; General Wheel-
er's name first. General Wheel-
er's complaint is, as I under-
stand, that a provision which he
inserted with his name was not
quoted in the telegram.
